on a m√™me parl√© √† plusieurs reprises, digital humanities is a tool in your toolbox, rather than a new discipline (this doesn't mean there aren't particular and essential methodological reflections) that you use to answer historical (or other) questions.

In "What is Digital Humanities and What's It Doing in English Departments?" I thought it was interesting that the author believes that the digital humanities has been "galvanized" by younger people. I think this is a common way of thinking and creates a cycle of younger vs. older

I liked that "A Short Guide to the Digital Humanities" mentioned the challenges that the digital humanities face. When it mentioned digital vs. print based storytelling, I thought of my own preference for print books, but the convenience that digital offers me on the go everyday.

In "What is Digital Humanities?" I liked that the author of the quote mentioned that digital humanities links communities together. Even though digital humanities can be made up of so many things, it all still connects together to create a diverse community.

#GAMS (https://t.co/7LOUAtOp5U) is based on the open source project #Fedora and is continuously developed within the framework of cooperation projects to take specific research interests into account. @DH_Graz #digitalDHaustria https://t.co/hbL5Q8MJGn

#GAMS relies on XML-based data archiving and presentation. If the data is not in an accepted XML-based standard, the Centre for Information Modelling @DH_Graz implements a conversion workflow in coordination with project partners. #digitalDHaustria  https://t.co/hbL5Q8MJGn

The Geisteswissenschaftliche Asset Management System (#GAMS) is an #OAIS-compliant asset management system for the administration, publication and long-term archiving of digital resources from all humanities subjects. @DH_Graz  #digitalDHaustria  https://t.co/hbL5Q8MJGn

The collection of the Bavarian Dialects in the region of the Austro-Hungarian Empire  includes a five-volume dictionary covering a period from the beginning of German language until the present. #digitalDHaustria #exploreAT! https://t.co/qr6oOjAvXh

The corpus of the collection (1911-1998) of the Bavarian Dialects in the region of the Austro-Hungarian Empire is large and rich, estimated to contain 200,000 headwords in around 4 Million records. #exploreAT! #digitalDHaustria https://t.co/qr6oOjS6OP
exploreAT! aims to reveal unique insights into the rich texture of the German language, especially in Austria. #digitalDHaustria  https://t.co/qr6oOjS6OP

Via the "EventSearch" interface, all events in digital editions that are coded in that particular format can be automatically queried and evaluated for further content analysis. #digitalDHaustria  https://t.co/JD99rlpB1Z

In the project "EventSearch API", the encoding of events is modelled within the framework of #TEI with an emphasis on flat hierarchy in order to keep the data migration for all edition projects as simple as possible. #digitalDHaustria  https://t.co/JD99rlHcqz

With the "EventSearch API", a machine-readable interface (#API) is developed for events marked in this #TEI format. EventSearch makes it possible to make the encoded events of different digital editions more visible and searchable. #digitalDHaustria https://t.co/JD99rlpB1Z
